newsitem.title: FRANCE: Airbus confirms Dragonair buying two A320 jets.
newsitem.headline: Airbus confirms Dragonair buying two A320 jets.

text.p: European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie confirmed on Thursday that Hong Kong Dragon Airlines (Dragonair) has signed a contract to buy two Airbus A320 narrow-body passenger jets and has placed five more under option.
The airline will also lease a wide-body A330-300 twinjet from International Lease Finance Corp (ILFC), a unit of American International Group, Airbus said in a statement.
The A320s will be powered by V2537-A5 engines from International Aero Engines. Industry sources in Hong Kong said earlier this month Dragonair was poised to acquire the planes.
Dragonair already flies four A330 and seven A320s in its fleet.
The A320 carries 168 passengers in an economy class layout or 156 in two classes.
The A330, powered by Rolls-Royce Trent 700 engines, can carry 36 in first class and 264 in the main cabin.
List price for an A320 is around $47 million and about $113 million for an A330.

Airbus Industrie is a consortium made up of French state-owned Ste Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale, British Aerospace Plc, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, a unit of Daimler-Benz AG and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA (CASA) of Spain.
